facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 25 of 1954 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 25 of 1954.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave granted by Supreme Court on 11th December 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court of India by its Order dated the 11th December, 1953, from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th

facts.text: Election Tribunal Cuttack passed judgment and order on 16th November 1953 in Election Case No. 4 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: from the Judgment and Order dated the 16th November, 1953, of the Election Tribunal, Cuttack, in Election Case No. 4 of 1952.

facts.text: Election Tribunal set aside election of appellant to Legislative Assembly Orissa from Kendrapara Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the order of the Election Tribunal, Cuttack, setting aside the election of the appellant to the Legislative Assembly, Orissa, from the Kend

facts.text: Four persons including appellant and respondents 1 to 3 nominated for election.

anchor.surface_text: Four persons, the appellant and respondents Nos. 1 to 3, were duly nominated for election to the seat.

facts.text: Loknath Das third respondent withdrew candidature.

anchor.surface_text: One of them, Loknath Das the third respondent herein , withdrew his candidature, leaving the contest to the other three.

facts.text: Election held between 9th and 15th January 1952.

anchor.surface_text: At the election which was held between 9th and 15th January, 1952,

facts.text: Appellant secured largest number of votes and declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant secured the largest number of votes and was declared elected.

facts.text: Jadumoni Mangaraj respondent no.1 presented petition under section 81 RPA 1951 alleging corrupt practices by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Jadumoni Mangaraj, then presented a petition under section 81 of the Representation of the people Act No. XLIII of 1951 alleging various corrupt practices on the part

facts.text: Last date for presenting petition was 4th April 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for presenting the petition was 4th April, 1952.

facts.text: Petition delivered at post office Cuttack on 3rd April 1952 for registered post.

anchor.surface_text: It was delivered at the post office at Cuttack on 3rd April, 1952, for being sent by registered post,

facts.text: Petition reached Election Commission Delhi on 5th April 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and actually reached the Election Commission at Delhi on 5th April, 1952, a day beyond the period prescribed.

facts.text: Petition had defective verification not specifying paragraphs on personal knowledge vs information.

anchor.surface_text: It was also defective in its verification. Section 83 (1) of the Act enacts that the petition should be verified in the manner laid down in the Civil Procedure Code for the verification of the pleadings. Order VI, rule 15, sub- clause (2), of the Civil Procedure Code provides that the person verifying shall specify by reference to the numbered paragraphs of the pleading what he verifies on his own knowledge and what he verifies upon information received and believed to be true.

facts.text: Election Commission condoned delay on 2nd July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On 2nd July, 1952, the Election Commission passed an order condoning the delay in the presentation of the petition.

facts.text: Election Commission drew attention to verification defect on 3rd July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By another communication, dated 3rd July, 1952, it drew the attention of the petitioner to the defect in the verification,

facts.text: Election Tribunal appointed on 15th July 1952 under section 86.

anchor.surface_text: On 15th July, 1952 an order was passed under section 86 of the Act appointing the Election Tribunal, Cuttack, for the hearing of the petition.

facts.text: Verification amended on 24th July 1952 to comply with CPC Order VI rule 15(2).

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner then applied to the Election Tribunal for amending the verification. That was ordered, and the verification was amended on 24th July, 1952, so as to conform to the prescriptions laid down in Order VI, rule 15 (2), of the Civil Procedure Code.

facts.text: Election Tribunal held by majority that appellant induced third respondent Loknath Das to withdraw on promise of employment violating s.123(1).

anchor.surface_text: it held by a majority that three of the corrupt practices set out in the petition had been established against the appellant. They were (1) that the appellant had, in violation of section 123 (1) of the Act, induced the third respondent to withdraw from the election on a promise to get him employment

facts.text: Election Tribunal found appellant used Bus No. O.R.C. 1545 for conveying electors to polling booths violating s.123(6).

anchor.surface_text: (2) that he had, in breach of section 123 (6) of the Act, used Bus No. O.R.C. 1545 for conveying the electors to polling booths

facts.text: Election Tribunal found appellant obtained assistance of Extra Departmental Agents and Presidents of Choukidari Union violating s.123(8).

anchor.surface_text: and (3) that he had, in contravention of section 123 (8) of the Act, obtained the assistance of Extra Departmental Agents in branch post offices and of Presidents of Choukidari Union in canvassing for him in the election,

facts.text: Supreme Court found the findings on promise to third respondent and bus usage supported by evidence, not perverse.

anchor.surface_text: the findings in this case that the appellant got the third respondent to withdraw on a promise to get him employment, and had used Bus No. O.R.C. 1545 for conveying voters to the polling booths, are supported by the evidence, and cannot be characterised as perverse,

facts.text: Appellant contended petition not maintainable due to delay and defective verification.

anchor.surface_text: In the written statement filed by the appellant, he raised the contention that as the petition was presented out of time and as the verification was defective, it was liable to be dismissed

facts.text: Election Tribunal proceeded to hear petition on merits despite contentions.

anchor.surface_text: Disagreeing with this contention, the Election Tribunal proceeded to hear the petition on the merits,

issues.text: Whether this Court, when hearing appeals under Article 136, interferes with findings of fact by the Election Tribunal unless perverse or based on no evidence?

anchor.surface_text: But this Court does not, when hearing appeals under article 136, sit as a Court of further appeal on facts, and does not interfere with findings given on a consideration of the evidence, unless they are perverse or based on no evidence. This is particularly so,

issues.text: Whether the findings of the Election Tribunal that the appellant committed corrupt practices under sections 123(1), 123(6) and 123(8) of the RPA are perverse or based on no evidence warranting interference under Article 136?

anchor.surface_text: They are pure questions of fact, depending on appreciation of evidence. Mr. Krishnaswami Ayyangar, learned counsel for the appellant, argued that the conclusion of the majority were not justified by the evidence or record, and that the findings of the third member in his dissentient opinion were the right ones to come to But this Court does

issues.text: Whether the election petition was liable to be dismissed under section 85 of the RPA for being presented beyond the time prescribed by section 81?

anchor.surface_text: counsel for the appellant concentrated on the issues relating to the maintainability of the petition. He contended that as the petition was not presented within the time as required by section 81 of the Act, it was liable to be dismissed under the mandatory provision in section 85,

issues.text: Whether the Election Commission could condone the delay in presenting the petition suo motu under the proviso to section 85 without an application by the petitioner, notice to the respondent, or personal appearance of the petitioner?

anchor.surface_text: The contention of Mr. Krishnaswami Ayyangar is that the order is not valid, because it was passed not on any application of the party praying that the delay might be excused but suo motu and such an application, it is contended, is a condition to the exercise of jurisdiction under that proviso.

issues.text: Whether there was sufficient cause for condoning the one-day delay in presentation of the petition under the proviso to section 85?

anchor.surface_text: With particular reference to the order dated 2nd July, 1952, it is difficult to come to any conclusion other than that in passing that order the discretion under the proviso to section 85 has been properly exercised. The petition had been presented at the post office one day earlier,

issues.text: Whether the Election Tribunal had discretion under section 90(4) to refuse to dismiss the petition despite non-compliance with sections 81, 83 or 117, overriding section 85?

anchor.surface_text: Under section 90 (4) of the Act, when the petition does not comply with the requirements of section 81, section 83 or section 117, the Election Tribunal has a discretion either to dismiss it or not, notwithstanding anything contained in section 85.

issues.text: Whether the Election Tribunal could condone the defective verification under section 83 read with Order VI Rule 15(2) CPC by amendment and refusal to dismiss under section 90(4)?

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.85 does not require application, notice, enquiry or personal appearance; EC can condone suo motu; final decision.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to section 85 does not contemplate the Election Commission giving to the respondent notice of the petition for condonation of the delay, or the holding of an enquiry as to the sufficiency of the grounds in his presence before passing an order under it.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of an order under section 90 (4) declining to dismiss the petition on the ground of delay or defective verification is clearly to condone those defects. In the instant case, with reference to the, plea of limi- tation the position stands thus

holdings.text: This Court does not, when hearing appeals under article 136, sit as a Court of further appeal on facts, and does not interfere with findings given on a consideration of the evidence, unless they are perverse or based on no evidence. This is particularly so, when the findings under challenge are those of Election Tribunals.

anchor.surface_text: But this Court does not, when hearing appeals under article 136, sit as a Court of further appeal on facts, and does not interfere with findings given on a consideration of the evidence, unless they are perverse or based on no evidence. This is particularly so,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies established precedent on scope of Art 136 review, especially for Election Tribunals; distinguishes from ordinary appeals.

holdings.text: The findings in this case that the appellant got the third respondent to withdraw on a promise to get him employment, and had used Bus No. O.R.C. 1545 for conveying voters to the polling booths, are supported by the evidence, and cannot be characterised as perverse, and are therefore not open to attack in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examines evidence; applies perverse/no evidence standard under Art 136; accepts Tribunal's appreciation as non-perverse.

holdings.text: The order dated 2nd July, 1952 condoning the delay is valid and the discretion under the proviso to section 85 has been properly exercised.

anchor.surface_text: With particular reference to the order dated 2nd July, 1952, it is difficult to come to any conclusion other than that in passing that order the discretion under the proviso to section 85 has been properly exercised. The petition had been presented

holdings.reasoning_summary: One-day delay posted timely; liberal construction of sufficient cause per precedent; proper exercise even under Limitation Act analogy.

holdings.text: The proviso to section 85 does not require an application by the petitioner; Election Commission may condone delay suo motu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation: proviso silent on application; distinguishes Limitation Act s.5; statutory rights not common law.

holdings.text: Proviso to section 85 does not contemplate notice to respondent or enquiry before condoning delay; treats as matter between EC and petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: The proviso to section 85 does not contemplate the Election Commission giving to the respondent notice of the petition for condonation of the delay, or the holding of an enquiry as to the sufficiency of the grounds in his presence before passing

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory policy: EC decision final; no provision for notice/enquiry; contrasts with Limitation Act where reviewable.

holdings.text: There was sufficient cause for the one-day delay, warranting condonation under proviso to s.85.

holdings.text: Proviso to s.85 does not require personal appearance of petitioner to satisfy EC.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language requires satisfaction on sufficient cause, not mandating personal appearance; no such implication in proceedings.

holdings.text: Under section 90(4), Election Tribunal has discretion to dismiss or not for non-compliance with ss.81,83,117 notwithstanding s.85.

anchor.surface_text: Under section 90 (4) of the Act, when the petition does not comply with the requirements of section 81, section 83 or section 117, the Election Tribunal has a discretion either to dismiss it or not, notwithstanding anything contained in section 85.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual/harmonious construction: s.90(4) overrides s.85; applies to factual non-dismissal under s.85; enables condonation.

holdings.text: Election Tribunal's refusal to dismiss under s.90(4) for delay or defective verification, and allowing amendment, condones defects validly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Discretion under s.90(4) post s.86 transfer; amendment ordered 24 July 1952; no review of EC.

anchor.surface_text: Jagan Nath v. Jaswant Singh 1 , the rights under litigation in these proceedings are not common law rights but rights which owe their existence to statutes, and the extent of those rights must be determined by reference to the statutes which create them.

precedents.cited_proposition: the rights under litigation in these proceedings are not common law rights but rights which owe their existence to statutes, and the extent of those rights must be determined by reference to the statutes which create them

anchor.surface_text: Vide the decision of the Privy Council in Krishnasami Panikondar v. Ramasami Chettiar 1 . It was argued that in this view the respondent would be without remedy even if the Election Commission should choose to condone delays-it might be of years-, and that that would result in great hardship.

precedents.cited_proposition: under section 5 of the Limitation Act, an order excusing delay is not final, and is liable to be questioned by the respondent at a later stage

anchor.surface_text: As was observed in the Full Bench ,decision in Krishna v. Chathappan 2 , in a passage which has become classic, the words Sufficient cause should receive a liberal construction so as to advance substantial justice when nonegligence none inaction none want of bona fides is imputable to the appellant.
